output.conclusion: By the end of this course, you will have a solid understanding of how technology can be ethically and effectively integrated into rewilding projects, enabling you to contribute to more impactful and sustainable conservation efforts.
output.courseTitle: Rewilding with Tech: An Intermediate Guide
output.introduction: Welcome to Rewilding with Tech! This course is designed for individuals with some existing knowledge of rewilding principles and a basic understanding of technology. We will explore how technology can be leveraged to enhance rewilding efforts, focusing on practical applications and ethical considerations.

chapters.chapterTitle: Module 1: Introduction to Rewilding and Technology
chapters.description: This module introduces the core concepts of rewilding and explores the potential of technology to accelerate and enhance these efforts. We will cover the basics of rewilding principles, the role of technology in conservation, and the ethical considerations involved in using technology for rewilding.
A review of the core principles of rewilding, including trophic cascades, keystone species, and passive management.
An overview of how technology is currently used in conservation, including examples of successful applications.
A discussion of the ethical implications of using technology in rewilding, including data privacy, environmental impact, and community engagement.

chapters.chapterTitle: Module 2: Remote Sensing and GIS for Rewilding
chapters.description: This module focuses on the use of remote sensing and Geographic Information Systems (GIS) in rewilding projects. We will explore how these technologies can be used to monitor ecosystems, track wildlife populations, and assess the effectiveness of rewilding interventions.
An introduction to remote sensing technologies, including satellite imagery, aerial photography, and LiDAR.
How GIS can be used to map habitats, analyze spatial data, and create visualizations for rewilding projects.
Real-world examples of how remote sensing and GIS have been used to support rewilding efforts.

This module explores the use of various technologies for monitoring wildlife populations in rewilding projects. We will cover camera traps, acoustic monitoring, GPS tracking, and other tools for gathering data on animal behavior, distribution, and abundance.
Best practices for deploying and managing camera traps, including camera selection, placement, and data analysis.
Using acoustic sensors to monitor animal vocalizations and track biodiversity.
How GPS collars and other tracking devices can be used to study animal movement and habitat use.

This module focuses on the importance of data management and analysis in rewilding projects. We will explore tools and techniques for organizing, analyzing, and visualizing data collected from various sources, including remote sensing, GIS, and wildlife monitoring technologies.
Best practices for data storage, organization, and documentation.
An overview of statistical and spatial analysis methods for rewilding data.
Creating effective visualizations to communicate rewilding data to stakeholders.
